Name: Mario San Jose Geisha
Review: ong>A brilliant example of the original Gesha profile, for those who can afford it.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a natural, honeyish sweetness and jammy fruit in a very clean dried-in-the-fruit profile.

Name: Ethiopia Dry Process Saris Abaya
Review: ong>A floral-toned, slightly savory version of the great chocolate-and-brandy southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit profile.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo
Review: ong>The play of sweetness – honey, blueberry – against crisper notes – roasted cocoa nib, herb – gives this dried-in-the-fruit profile its particular distinction.

Name: Idido Cooperative Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Review: ong>Sweet and floral but delicately dry, should please lovers of Rieslings and similar styles of white table wine.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Aromatics stretch nicely from earthy base through chocolate to fruit; impressively lively mouthfeel. Maintains presence well in milk.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Brazil; northern Sumatra, Indonesia; southern Ethiopia.

Name: Espresso
Review: ong>A sophisticated darker roasted espresso, with the roast contributing some pungent bittersweet character without muting aromatics or thinning an impressively full mouthfeel and substantial presence in milk.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Brazil; Huila Department, southwestern Colombia.

Name: Summit Winter Blend
Review: ong>A soothing but engaging holiday blend that should make a small contribution to peace, on earth and at the dinner table.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Classically please-em-all holiday blend, though aficionados might find this updated version of the ancient Mocha-Java blend interesting for its blend composition. The Java, as it does in the original blend archetype, contributes a rounding base; in this case supporting a gently bright, crisply berry-toned Kenya.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>A versatile, drinkable holiday blend with attractive social and environmental credentials at a very attractive price.

Name: Fa-La-La-La-La
Review: ong>Subtle authority and gentle sweetness; excellent holiday value.

Name: Colombia San Agustin Arnulfo Leguizamo
Review: ong>A pure, deep-toned, full-bodied cup in the classic Colombia style. Produced from trees of the Caturra variety, a selection of Bourbon that is usually rather basic in the cup, but that here displays some of the celebrated pungent berry character of its parent.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Original Christmas (SO Yirgacheffe)
Review: ong>Not a holiday blend, but a felicitous choice of single-origin coffee that expresses an appropriately winter holiday sensory theme of fruit, chocolate and pleasingly pungent aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopia Nekisse
Review: ong>Superb version of the Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” profile, with the complex, juicy sweetness of the type expressed with unusual purity and vivacity.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Rwanda Abakundakawa
Review: ong>Certainly the sweetest, and probably the best, Rwanda we have sampled for some time. The sweetness is the natural kind, a deeply nuanced expression of orchard-like purity enriched by a tactfully caramelizing roast. You certainly don’t need sweetener for this one.

Name: Jingle Bell Natural Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Great depth, range and balance of sensation make this an exceptional choice for any season, any holiday.

Name: Panama La Esmeralda Especial
Review: ong>As refreshing and heady as a tropical morning, a cliché that seems absolutely justified by this light, levitating version of the rare Gesha variety. Buy it close to when you’re going to drink it, and if you give it, make sure it doesn’t sit in the gift pile too long.

Name: Kenya Kamviu
Review: ong>Simply a superb, complete coffee; the great Kenya style at its finest.

Name: Panama Don Pachi Natural Geisha
Review: ong>A light but fully developed roast foregrounds an extraordinary version of a very rare coffee. If you splurge on it for the holidays do your splurging close to when you are planning to drink the coffee, brew it carefully, and leave the sweetener on the counter and the dairy in the fridge.

Name: Perci Red Panama Gesha
Review: ong>Anyone who can afford it. An amazing coffee.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Pandora Del Carmen Pacamara
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in enjoying the deep, low-toned, savory fruit tendencies of the Pacamara variety.

Name: La Esperanza Guatemala Huehuetenango
Review: ong>Those who understand and appreciate a classically bright coffee. There is nothing sour, bitter or astringent here; instead a lushly sweet-toned, flavor-nuanced tart sensation vibrates at the heart of the profile.

Name: Gentle Hades
Review: ong>Those who enjoy roundly rich, syrupy espressos.

Name: Lightning Athena
Review: ong>Those who enjoy zesty, brisk espressos.

Name: Papua New Guinea Kimel
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the quietly exotic.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Glory Hank
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a pleasing balance of tart fruit and oaky chocolate in straight shot and milk.
Coffee Origin: Tanzania; India; Bolivia; Panama; Colombia; Guatemala.

Name: Bali Kintamani
Review: ong>An aficionado’s dried-in-the-fruit coffee with the brandy-like appeal of the type complicated by hints of clove and sandalwood.

Name: Colombia La Esperanza Cerro Azul Geisha
Review: ong>I can’t call a coffee this expensive a bargain, but it is less expensive than the more celebrated Panama Geshas, and given its extraordinary complexity and character, an excellent value for those who appreciate and can afford the genuinely exceptional.

Name: Colombia Geisha
Review: ong>A balanced, elegant version of the extravagantly aromatic Gesha profile.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Finca El Injerto Patagonia, Guatemala
Review: ong>The crisply sweet berry character of great Kenyas shows up here in this very distinctive, resonantly elegant profile.

Name: Aroma de Canalaj Guatemala
Review: ong>Deep, whisky-and-honey aromatic character may make this cup a particularly good afternoon or evening choice.

Name: Finca El Socorro Maracaturra, Guatemala
Review: ong>Delicately complex, sweet, very slightly savory, a subtly unusual profile for subtle palates.

Name: Colombia Geisha (K-Cup)
Review: ong>For K-cuppers an unusual opportunity to sample one of the world’s most celebrated (and expensive) coffees, the Gesha variety of Arabica. A nice gift for the K-cup aficionado.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Bourbon Duets
Review: ong>A superb espresso, exotic and distinctive both as straight shot and in short milk.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Aroma Roast
Review: ong>A coffee exhilaratingly exotic in its aromatics yet cleanly articulated and classic in structure.

Name: Limited Edition True Espresso
Review: ong>For those relatively new to espresso an accessible and easy drinking straight shot. For espresso enthusiasts the prominent vanilla note may be remarkable.

Name: Kenya Echo
Review: ong>For those connoisseurs interested in sampling a distinctive single-origin espresso.

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango Finca La Bolsa
Review: ong>Classic Guatemalan variation on the classic American breakfast cup: sweetly acidy, big-bodied, complex, rich.

Name: Ethiopia Konga
Review: ong>A brisk, rather elegant bittersweet character makes this an unusual variation on the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Mexico Chiapas Phoenix Special S.O. Espresso
Review: ong>Impressive aromatic range and complexity with pleasing mouthfeel in the straight shot; fades a bit in milk.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth and savory sweetness in a versatile espresso.

Name: Kenya AA
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry, spicy, floral-toned white table wines.

Name: Mocha-Java Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy rich, savory-sweet beverages. Should take whitener well.
Coffee Origin: Mattari growing region Yemen; Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Mandheling growing region, Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Lycello Panama Gesha
Review: ong>Giddily sweet and complex expression of the Gesha cup. If you can afford it, try it.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Blue Batak Peaberry
Review: ong>A superb, unapologetic Sumatra of the deep, cleanly and richly earthy style.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: El Salvador Los Pirineos Natural Red Bourbon
Review: ong>Exotic, richly brandy-toned cup for coffee adventurers.

Name: Honduras Maria Galo
Review: ong>Classic Central American breakfast cup: balanced, juicy, complete.

Name: Guatemala San Juan
Review: ong>Those who prefer red wines and whisky to white wines and vodka.

Name: Honduras Seydi Argueta
Review: ong>Lovers of crisply complex, dry white table wines.
Coffee Origin: La Paz District, Marcala growing region, Honduras.

Name: Classic Roast
Review: ong>Very low price; very, very poor quality by any standard that we know of.

Name: 100% Colombian
Review: ong>We’ve tasted this brand and this coffee when it was considerably better. Maybe you’ll get lucky with yours.

Name: 100% Colombian
Review: ong>Nothing wrong; nothing much right here either except for the very attractive price. A clean but very simple, woody cup.

Name: Organic Rainforest Blend
Review: ong>Lovers of ultra-dark “French” roasts and organic agriculture. A little more flavor nuance at considerably less money than offered by most such super-dark blends, organic or otherwise.

Name: Veranda Blend Blonde
Review: ong>Those looking for Starbucks’ version of “mellow and soft” (very) at an attractive price.

Name: Breakfast Blend Rainforest Alliance
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a cleanly delicate medium roast at a reasonable price.

Name: House Blend Medium Roast
Review: ong>Decent, balanced dark roast at a very attractive price.

Name: Major Dickason’s Blend
Review: ong>Peetniks and other dark-roast lovers on a budget.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Amaro Gayo
Review: ong>A cigar-and-leather-armchair style coffee, deep and richly brandy-like.

Name: Karatu Kenya AA
Review: ong>Classic Kenya: intense, elegant, complex.

Name: La Colmena El Salvador Pacamara
Review: ong>Unusual coffee, perhaps more distinguished than our rating suggests. Those who value dry, savory undercurrents in beverages – in aged tequilas and cachaças, to give just two examples – should particularly enjoy this coffee.

Name: Kenya Mamuto
Review: ong>The celebrated Kenya dry berry character, aka “black currant,” for us displayed here as sweetly tangy, juicy guava. Everything works in this superbly complete, graceful coffee, simultaneously simple and complex, altogether classic.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe ECX Top Lot
Review: ong>Those who find typical Yirgacheffes too light-bodied and floral may particularly enjoy this variant on the type, with its fuller mouthfeel and emphasis on lemon and deeper fig-molasses notes.

Name: Organic Costa Rica Helsar Finca Santa Lucia
Review: ong>Delicate, lively, silky cup should please palates tuned to subtlety.

Name: Guatemala Quetzel
Review: ong>A balanced, quietly complex cup with thorough-going socially and environmentally progressive credentials.

Name: Kenya Thunguri – Top Auction Lot
Review: ong>Aficionados or anyone interested in a particularly deep, pungently lush variation on the classic Kenya cup.

Name: Ethiopia Michiti Cooperative
Review: ong>Sweet, intense Ethiopia with classic citrus and flowers.
Coffee Origin: Kefa (Kaffa) Province, Oromia region, southwestern Ethiopia.

Name: Guatemala Finca El Valle
Review: ong>A characteristically suave and quietly balanced coffee from the celebrated Antigua valley.

Name: Panama Gesha Estates: Perci Estate 29 Natural
Review: ong>Aficionados who can afford another extraordinary variation on the great Gesha profile: balanced, deep, vibrant, lush.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AA Tegu
Review: ong>Those interested in sampling a superb example of the classic Kenya SL28 cup combining great sweetness, gently tart, pungent fruit and lush flowers.

Name: Kenya Ngunguru Cooperative
Review: ong>Fine variant on the great Kenya profile: Vivacious, sweetly bright, juicy.

Name: Seattle Space Blend
Review: ong>Straight-shot drinkers may be particularly impressed by the complexity, range and balance of this blend, with its bright but smoothly juicy fruit notes wrapped in rounding chocolate and aromatic wood.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha
Review: ong>Those interested in sampling a delicately elegant but very distinctive variation on the great Gesha profile.

Name: Michigan Bright, Coffees for Change
Review: ong>Persuasive local cause, nicely balanced cup.

Name: Bullet Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the natural, complex sweetness of roasted cocoa nib in a gently roast-rounded coffee.

Name: Dominican Republic Cafe Femenino Organic Fair Trade
Review: ong>Crisp, delicate cup offers impressive support for low-income women both in the Dominican Republic through the Café Femenino program and to local women in crisis in Columbus, Ohio.

Name: Cafe Femenino Rwandan
Review: ong>Unusual cup with quietly distinctive aroma and flavor contributing to an important cause.

Name: Amy’s Blend
Review: ong>A rather rough-edged but vigorous, engaging blend supporting a timely cause with personal resonance at Caribou.

Name: Song Bird Shade Grown Coffee
Review: ong>Gently lively cup for backyard birders and anyone who prefers mellow to bright.

Name: Medium Coffee
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a roundly pungent cup with relatively low acidity and who admire the uncompromisingly hands-on approach of this community-based roaster.

Name: Gabriel’s Grand Cru Micro-Lot 0086
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gentle, roundly brisk cup offered by an idealistic branch of a six-generation Brazilian farming family.

Name: Flor Del Sol Signature Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy exhilarating aromatics, a briskly tart structure and grassroots soccer.

Name: Ethiopian Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>An unusual dried-in-the-fruit profile, honeyish but pungent and deep. Nice any time, but should make an exceptional late-in-the-day cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Goldilocks Espresso
Review: ong>Intense but balanced espresso, dynamic in the small cup and suavely complex in short milk.

Name: Ethiopia Hachira
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in sampling one of the most original and striking dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopian coffees to appear this year.

Name: Ethiopia Birhanu
Review: ong>A fine variation on the classic washed Yirgacheffe profile, with exhilarating lime and lush floral notes.

Name: El Banco Espresso (El Salvador Pacamara)
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a straight shot with full but lively mouthfeel and a balanced complexity.

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the extravagant intensity of southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.

Name: El Salvador Las Delicias Pacamara SOE Blend
Review: ong>A fine, versatile espresso with great range and depth of sensation yet fundamental balance and completeness.
Coffee Origin: Nejapa, San Salvador Department, El Salvador.

Name: Roastmaster’s Reserve Esmeralda
Review: ong>An opportunity to taste the spectacular Gesha profile at peak complexity and nuance. Reasonably priced for an Esmeralda Gesha.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha
Review: ong>Super aficionados on a budget. A (believe it or not) reasonably priced version of the extravagantly distinctive and rare Esmeralda Gesha.
Coffee Origin: Canas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: Ethiopian Konga Co-op Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>An adventurer’s coffee, deeply and idiosyncratically complex with aromatic surprises from aroma through finish.

Name: JWF Blend
Review: ong>Appealingly complex and deep as a straight shot. Simplifies in milk, but maintains authority and fruit-toned character.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Organic
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in a very cleanly and originally expressed version of the Ethiopia natural cup; anyone who enjoys exotic but balanced complexity.

Name: The Academics Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy an espresso that balances tart authority with chocolaty sweetness.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Wote Konga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sensory excitement and surprise.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Wote Konga
Review: ong>Those who can handle both intensity and complexity in a striking and unusual coffee.

Name: Nicaragua Marlene Lagos Honey
Review: ong>A contemplative sort of coffee, deep, quiet, sweet without sentiment.

Name: Ugandan Mountains of the Moon
Review: ong>Those who enjoy deep, authoritative, richly stated coffees with a hint of roasty pungency.

Name: Panama Don Pachi Natural Geisha
Review: ong>Those who can afford a finely executed dried-in-the-fruit version of the great Gesha profile.

Name: Kenya Roastmaster’s Reserve
Review: ong>An easy-going Kenya, with the sweetly tart berry character of fine Kenyas but without their often challengingly bright acidity.

Name: El Salvador Malacara Pulped Natural
Review: ong>Those who enjoy subtle, gentle beverages.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.

Name: Costa Rica La Candelilla Honey Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy white wines that are delicate and crisply dry yet sweet.

Name: Costa Rica El Espino Yellow Honey Caturra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy subtly sweet breakfast coffees with understated acidity.
Coffee Origin: Zarcero Canton, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica.

Name: El Salvador SHG Honey Bourbon
Review: ong>The honey process deepens and rounds the characteristically tart Bourbon fruit, making this a good choice for aficionados exploring a variation on the great Bourbon profile, and for anyone who prefers rich pungency to bright acidity.

Name: Nicaragua Plantio el Aserradero
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in a coffee with a subtly unusual profile, a little Sumatra-like, a little natural-Brazil-like, but ultimately unique in its damply woodsy and nut-toned character.
Coffee Origin: Mozonte district, Nuevo Segovia Department, Nicaragua.

Name: El Salvador El Manzano
Review: ong>A subtle coffee subtly light-roasted produces a crisply delicate, refreshing cup.

Name: Costa Rica Herbazu Villa Sarchi Honey
Review: ong>Honey character in a honey coffee; a walk in the woods in the springtime.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: El Salvador El Rubi Honey
Review: ong>Coffee iconoclasts. Complex and unexpected.

Name: El Salvador La Roxanita Pulped Natural
Review: ong>Very sweet, quite tart; those who don’t normally care for tartly acidy coffees may be persuaded by this deep, richly subtle rendition.

Name: El Salvador Casas de Lamina
Review: ong>Lovers of fruity, lightly fermented dried-in-the-fruit “natural” coffees should particularly enjoy this coffee, which treads the same sensory track as fruity naturals but with a bit more subtlety.
Coffee Origin: Apaneca district, Ahuachapan Department, El Salvador.

Name: Ethiopian ECX Top Lot
Review: ong>Those in pursuit of intensity; a flamboyant and bracing cup.

Name: Costa Rican Miguel Rojas Miso
Review: ong>Not a showy cup, but a quietly complex, quite comfortable one.

Name: Signature Mocha Java
Review: ong>A quiet but delicately complex morning cup.

Name: Barista Prima Coffeehouse Colombia (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A subtle, floral-toned dark roast for Keurig owners.

Name: Gichugu Kenya Espresso
Review: ong>A superbly deep and balanced single-origin, straight-shot espresso, with the acidity turned from assertive to roundly rich by a skillful roast.

Name: Sidamo Guji
Review: ong>Impressively rich and complexly chocolate-toned variation on the dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe ECX Top Lot
Review: ong>A quiet but distinctive Yirgacheffe that should please those who like their flowers, citrus and cocoa in balance, present but not insistent.

Name: Mihuti Kenya AA
Review: ong>Sweet but crisp variant on the great Kenya profile.

Name: Ethiopia Nanno Challa Cooperative
Review: ong>Exhilaratingly exotic yet accessible, a coffee that should please both casual coffee drinkers and aficionados. Absolutely do not ruin this coffee with sweetener; should be very nice iced.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar
Review: ong>Lovers both of the old, funky Sumatras as well as the new, more refined (yet still intense) versions like this one.
Coffee Origin: Lake Tawar basin, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Panama Kotowa Duncan 2012 Microlot
Review: ong>The complex floral notes, which include spicy florals like aromatic tea rose and bitterish florals like lavender, are one good reason for aficionados to seek out this unusual coffee.
Coffee Origin: El Salto, Boquete growing region, Panama.

Name: Kenya Thiriku Top Auction Lot
Review: ong>A gently crisp, floral, refreshing version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Blue Special Blend
Review: ong>Complex straight shot with an impressive and classic range of sensation.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Mogiana growing region, Brazil; Thailand.

Name: Hama Blend
Review: ong>Balanced and gently complex as straight shot; delicately pleasing in short milk.

Name: Ethiopia Watadara Sidamo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the extravagant and uncompromising.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Honey Process Single-Estate Espresso
Review: ong>A quietly balanced espresso with good vanilla-toned chocolate character.
Coffee Origin: Bluekoff Estate, Chiang Rai Province, Thailand

Name: Dolok Sanggul Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>The pungent fruit and rich aromatic wood notes beloved by drinkers of fine Sumatra coffees manifest with both depth and elegance in this Sumatra single-origin espresso.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba growing region, northern Sumatra.

Name: S.O. Espresso Maui Mokka
Review: ong>A resonant, exotic straight shot. Should handle taller milk drinks well.
Coffee Origin: Kaanapali district, near Lahaina, West Maui, Hawaii

Name: Limited Edition Classic Espresso
Review: ong>Lovers of deep-toned, pungently rich espressos.

Name: Panama Elida Estate Reserve
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a bracingly bright old-fashioned American cup.

Name: Carmen Estate Natural Panama
Review: ong>Aficionados and coffee adventurers may enjoy this unusual dried-in-the-fruit profile, in which distinct floral notes are supported by backgrounded, savory, earth-toned suggestions.

Name: Panama Lerida Estate Sonia’s Crop
Review: ong>Those who enjoy heavily hopped ales and other pleasingly bitter-edged beverages.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha Baru
Review: ong>Honeyish, meadowy version of the great Gesha profile.
Coffee Origin: Cañas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: 2012 Esmeralda Special Natural Panama
Review: ong>Affluent aficionados interested in sampling a version of the great Gesha profile that foregrounds with almost disconcerting intensity its famous floral and cocoa tendencies.

Name: Panama Elida Natural
Review: ong>The style of coffee we used to call “after-dinner” coffee, meaning a rich, full-bodied, deeply complex coffee with acidity pushed to the background.

Name: Panama Geisha Honey Aroma Roast
Review: ong>Well-heeled lovers of the gently exotic; this Gesha displays a seemingly endless subtle, restless, teasing complexity.

Name: Panama Elida Estate Natural
Review: ong>More chocolaty depth and richness than brandy and fruit in this surprisingly clean and balanced dried-in-the-fruit natural.

Name: Panama Don Pachi Natural Geisha
Review: ong>Any coffee drinker with the cash to buy an amazing expression of sensory complexity.

Name: Esmeralda Leon, Panama Geisha Auction Lot
Review: ong>Those who can handle the price and the intensity: a Gesha on steroids.
Coffee Origin: Cañas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: Gelena Abaya Natural Processed Ethiopia
Review: ong>A splendid dried-in-the-fruit-style Ethiopia coffee, richly complex with the classic blueberry note often associated with the type.
Coffee Origin: Kersa district, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: ‘Bou Games Gold 2012
Review: ong>An admirably, indeed strikingly, unorthodox coffee from a major coffee company. If you are certain you only like pure, sweetly bright, classically clean high-grown coffees don’t bother with this one, but the open-minded should sample this deep, savory-sweet, whiskyish effort.

Name: Paradise A
Review: ong>An understated, nicely structured breakfast cup for those who prefer the calm to the dramatic.

Name: SpeedGoatKarl’s 100-Mile Blend
Review: ong>A woodsy kind of coffee, with its appealing roasted cocoa nib, cedar and honey suggestions.

Name: Kenyan AA Auction Lot
Review: ong>Aficionados should enjoy the remarkable tropical turn the tart, complex Kenya fruit takes here.

Name: Artemis True Coffee Blend
Review: ong>Versatile espresso should please both as a complex and exotic straight shot as well as an authoritative presence in milk drinks.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Grade 1
Review: ong>Those who enjoy lighter roasted coffees; in this case the lightish roast promotes the coffee’s rose-like floral character and a crisply lively acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Grade 1r
Review: ong>A breakfast cup both exotic in its aromatics and classic in its brisk, suavely balanced acidity.

Name: Guatemala Huixoc
Review: ong>Those who enjoy lighter-roasted coffees with delicately brisk acidity and fresh, meadowy aromatics.

Name: Kenya Kamwangi Peaberry
Review: ong>A darker roast turns the pungent Kenya fruit toward molasses and chocolate and deepens the flowers toward rose. A good Kenya for those who prefer depth to brightness.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda Espresso
Review: ong>A remarkably versatile single-origin espresso. Complex, round and sweetly crisp as a straight shot; rounds beautifully in milk. Should be authoritative enough to maintain presence in tall milk.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Grade 1
Review: ong>Unusual profile for coffee adventurers: Complex, very wide-ranging aromatics with an underlying savory depth to the sweetness.

Name: Tanzania Peaberry Kilimanjaro
Review: ong>Coffee lovers interested in sampling a distinctive version of an important historical coffee type. Botanical variety is not specified, but this sample tasted to us as though it brought some heirloom East Africa Bourbon or SL28 character to the cup.

Name: Ethiopian Kochere Teklu Dembel
Review: ong>Brisk, refreshing Yirgacheffe. The characteristic Yirgacheffe flowers are not heavy or jasmine-like, but breezy, spring-like and fresh.

Name: Ulos Batak Sumatra
Review: ong>A Sumatra taken through finishing school: elegant, poised, but with all of the fruit and forest intrigue intact.

Name: La Minita Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the contrast and excitement of rich, strongly stated acidity enveloped in great natural sweetness complicated by distinctive aromatics.

Name: Classico No.3 Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A versatile, complex straight shot that should appeal to a variety of tastes. Doesn’t quite impose its character on milk, though those who take pleasure in sweet, delicate short milk drinks should enjoy it.
Coffee Origin: Central America; South America; East Africa; Asia.

Name: Roytawan First Love Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a deep-toned, full-bodied espresso with a very discreet dark-roast edge.

Name: Maui Mokka Peaberry
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in sampling a particularly pure version of the famous Mocca profile. Anyone willing to pay more for an exciting, original yet elegantly balanced coffee.
Coffee Origin: Kaanapali district, near Lahaina, West Maui, Hawaii

Name: Rwanda Cafe Femenino
Review: ong>An opportunity to enjoy a fine Central Africa coffee with classic Bourbon-influenced crisp juiciness while supporting some of the many women who struggle to raise their families on very modest returns from small coffee farms.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Union Fair Trade
Review: ong>Those who enjoy light-roasted coffees with brilliantly complex aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe ECX Top Lot
Review: ong>Particularly brisk and complex version of the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Fair Trade Decaf Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A gift to drinkers of decaffeinated espresso: Impressive as a straight shot and even better in short milk.

Name: Wata Dara Ethiopian Sidamo Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Intense, dramatic, but refreshingly juicy Ethiopia for those who enjoy excitement at breakfast.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Microlot El Liano
Review: ong>The citrus and softly sweet chocolate suggestions animate a pleasing, drinkable morning cup.

Name: Rwanda
Review: ong>Fine moderately dark-roasted Rwanda, with the pungent, grapefruit notes and rich chocolate that coffees from the largely Bourbon variety plantings of Rwanda take on when deftly brought to a medium-dark roast like this one.

Name: Fair Trade Organic Sumatran Reserve (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A pleasantly rounded, bittersweet darker-roasted cup with reassuring environmental and social credentials for K-Cup drinkers.

Name: Hawaii Ka’u Rusty’s Typica Washed
Review: ong>A classic breakfast cup, sweet but brightly acidy.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Versatile if short-finishing blend: balanced, complexly layered straight shot displaying delicately nuanced chocolate in short milk.

Name: Little Sugar Blend Espresso
Review: ong>Cappuccino drinkers in particular should find this blend attractive, given the elegant way its dry chocolate and zesty orange round and blossom in the milk.

Name: Colombia Finca Buenavista
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the chocolate sensation at play in a complex matrix of fruit and floral nuance.

Name: Minor Espresso
Review: ong>Smooth and mild flavor as advertised; also depth and balanced richness.

Name: Fruitbomb Espresso
Review: ong>Not quite a bomb, but lots of fruit and fruit-toned chocolate for lovers of rich and brandyish straight shots.

Name: Espresso Gold Label
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big-bodied, quietly nuanced straight shots and delicate, balanced short milk drinks.

Name: Kenya AA Gatomboya
Review: ong>Kenya devotees. A finely nuanced, quietly original variation of the dry yet sweet, crisply layered floral and fruit Kenya cup.

Name: Taiwan Alishan Sumatra Honey
Review: ong>Those who enjoy natural sweetness in coffee, complexly sugary but not cloying.

Name: Sulawesi Toraja Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the most refined style of traditional Sumatra and Sulawesi coffees.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Colombia La Esperanza Cerro Azul Geisha
Review: ong>A very skillful light roasting emphasizes the great natural sweetness and the orchard-like freshness of the fruit and floral notes in this memorable rendition of the great Gesha profile.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Kona Maragogipe Honey S.O. Espresso
Review: ong>A giant-beaned gourmet curiosity that also offers an exceptional sensory experience.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Guatemala Antigua Phoenix Special Bourbon
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the brightness and complexity of a classic medium-roasted Arabica tactfully tamed for espresso cuisine.

Name: Sumatra Permata Gayo Fair Trade
Review: ong>Not a purist’s coffee, but a very pure example of its type, in which unorthodox tart fruit and earth notes animate a coffee with a profound sweetness and balance.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Phoenix Special
Review: ong>Lovers of complex, challengingly dry white wines.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Koke Espresso
Review: ong>A fine and versatile interpretation of the precious Yirgacheffe character as single-origin espresso.

Name: 100 Percent Mexican Organic
Review: ong>Gently bright and subtly nuanced breakfast cup in a rare Smithsonian Bird-Friendly-certified coffee.

Name: Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>Balanced, well-structured breakfast blend with simple but attractive aromatics and a pleasing dark chocolate nuance.

Name: Zhou Zhu Yuan Farm Taiwan Natural
Review: ong>Interesting coffee for aficionados, first because it is grown in Taiwan, a rare origin, and second because it offers an interesting variation on the lushly brandy-and-chocolate dried-in-the-fruit cup.

Name: 100 Percent Kona Coffee Extra Fancy Medium Roast
Review: ong>Balanced, medium-dark-roasted Kona with the chocolate and easy comfort associated with this famous origin.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Northern Lights Blend
Review: ong>Happy fence-sitters. Nicely situated on the cusp between medium- and moderately dark-roasted, with an easy-drinking caramel and plum character.
Coffee Origin: Kenya; Tanzania; Guatemala; Costa Rica; Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Kahindu Estate
Review: ong>Refined floral and deep fruit sweetness makes this an original and engaging variation on the great Kenya cup.

Name: Kenya AA Othaya
Review: ong>Complexly structured Kenya, sweet yet dry with savory hints. Should please those who enjoy drier, lighter bodied red table wines that keep the fruit in balance.

Name: Honduras Roastmaster’s Reserve
Review: ong>A deep, syrupy, complex cup suggests desserts and late, leisurely mornings.

Name: Bolivia Tres Estrellas Organic
Review: ong>The sweet floral and crisply cocoa-like aromatics are a good reason to try this quietly distinctive Bolivia.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi growing region, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Espresso Monk’s Momentum
Review: ong>The small cup offers an engaging sensory trajectory and the coffee gently retains character in short milk.

Name: Burundi Sogestal Mumirwa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry but floral/spicy white table wines may particularly enjoy this delicately complex coffee.

Name: Tanzania Mpito
Review: ong>Those who enjoy cleanly delicate, sweet-toned beverages.

Name: Tanzania Nzovu
Review: ong>Comfortable coffee: Brisk but not bright, pleasantly full in mouthfeel.

Name: Rwanda Buremera
Review: ong>Those who enjoy fruity/oaky red table wines and dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffees.

Name: Rwanda Kinunu
Review: ong>Gentle acidity and briskly complex aromatics should please those who enjoy fine black teas and lighter bodied, spicy red table wines.

Name: Burundi Kirimiro Teka Lot 2
Review: ong>Should please those who enjoy delicately dry, complexly floral white table wines.

Name: Burundi Ngozi Gihere 2
Review: ong>Gently dry in the mouthfeel yet sweet and berryish in flavor, this coffee defines an admired style of Bourbon cup from Central Africa.

Name: Burundi Kiryama Washing Station
Review: ong>Aficionados and others interested in the intriguingly complex floral character with its spicy/savory underpinning.
